abstract.text: A panel or sheet that lets the user edit the trust settings in any of the certificates in a certificate chain.

inlineContent.text: The following figure shows an example of a certificate trust panel.
You can use this class to enable a user to make trust decisions when one or more certificates required for an operation are invalid or cannot be verified.
To display a certificate in a panel or sheet without editable trust settings, use the
class. To display certificates in a custom view, use the

abstract.text: Provide user interface elements for security features such as authorization, access to digital certificates, and access to items in keychains.
Allows authorization plug-in developers to create a custom view their plug-in can display.
The class responsible for displaying a lock icon that can be used to indicate that a user interface has restricted access.
A panel or sheet that displays one or more certificates.
A panel or sheet that lets the user edit the trust settings in any of the certificates in a certificate chain.
Displays a modal sheet that shows the results of a certificate trust evaluation and that allows the user to edit trust settings.
Returns the (optional) informative text currently displayed in the panel.
Displays a modal panel that shows the results of a certificate trust evaluation and that allows the user to edit trust settings.
Sets the (optional) informative text displayed in the panel.
Returns a fully initialized, singleton certificate trust panel object.
A view that displays the contents of a certificate, with options to display certificate details, display trust settings, and allow users to edit a certificateâ€™s trust settings.
A panel or sheet containing a list of identities that a user can choose from.
A panel or sheet that allows the user to create a keychain.
A panel or sheet that allows users to change their keychain settings.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A protocol that a custom class can adopt to manage the enabled state of a UI element.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
